newsitem.title: USA: NYC official sees slow, steady rise in real estate.
newsitem.headline: NYC official sees slow, steady rise in real estate.

text.p: New York City's Finance Commissioner said Wednesday real estate prices were starting to rebound, with the market value for taxable property gaining 1.5 percent to $298.8 billion over last year.

Market values are the starting point for setting the value of the city's taxable real estate, said Fred Cerullo, the finance commissioner, adding the "billable assessed valuation" for the city was preliminarily set at $76.3 billion, a 1.09 percent rise over the previous year.
Real estate values are a major factor affecting the city's capital program because its debt ceiling, set by the state legislature, is based on a five-year average of these prices.

New York City's debt ceiling was expected to fall to under $31 billion over the next few months, and it is expected to run out of borrowing room by the end of its 1997 fiscal year, as using the five-year average slows down the impact of drops or rises in the real estate market.

The city has proposed a new infrastructure authority to issue debt for education and transportation as a way of sidestepping the debt cap, but the legislature failed to approve the measure at a special session in late December.

Cerullo, in prepared remarks, said "While property values have not rebounded to the boom levels of the 1980s real estate market, we are beginning to see a slow, but steady growth trend in overall property values." He singled out the hotels as the leading sector, gaining 10 percent as tourism grew, and noted that in a sharp reversal over last year's slip, residential apartment buidings rose 2.55 percent. And Manhattan units rose 3.6 percent as the luxury market boomed.
